Those defects actually can we can use it to our advantage. I have to admit I don't know exactly how but I have seen it used to other advantage in other fields. utterance: Chris Jones: Has anybody thought about the energetics of CO2 binding? So when you look at the most successful molecules or materials out there they have strong enthalpically driven binding because of course absorption is disfavored from an entropic perspective. But of course if you're going to swing it off you've got to you've got to repay that that enthalpy penalty. So are there strategies one could employ to design more physisorbing sites that would still absorb CO2 selectively? And the nice thing about some of the inorganic or hybrid materials like MOFs is you imagine that your toolbox is huge for the types of sites that you could potentially design. So could you design a very high density of more weakly binding sites and still grab enough CO2 at these ultra dilute conditions without having to repay that massive enthalpy penalty that all these strong chemisorbing materials pay?

annotations.ask question: The speaker requests information on the energetics of CO2 binding and potential strategies for material design.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker explores and expands on the concept of designing materials with specific properties for CO2 capture.

utterance: Oana Luca: Just to kind of add to the idea of electrifying the the CO2 capture component. utterance: Jennifer Wilcox: I wonder too if anybody's given any thought there's a lot of kind of companies emerging today that are looking at biomass waste and the conversion of biomass waste for hydrogen. Charm is one of them, Clean Energy Solutions, LanzaTech to some extent. But these these companies you know one of the things and and you might categorize this as BECCS a little bit. And so we we're familiar with things like blue hydrogen and green hydrogen but in the case of if you're using a biomass waste to produce hydrogen and in the production of that hydrogen you you separate out the CO2 and you store it you have the potential of producing negative hydrogen. And I think that you know that's something that's kind of new and I don't know if that's something you guys have given any thought to as an alternative source of hydrogen and it is a way of taking water out of the air because you're essentially using and exploiting photosynthesis right and CO2 of course. And there are some companies that are kind of thinking about this but not selling it in that way. But that's interesting. It's also just regional so you have to be careful because how much biomass waste is there out there? You know there's no silver bullet. But a little seed I want to plant if you haven't been thinking about that.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces a new concept of producing 'negative hydrogen' through biomass waste conversion with CO2 storage.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker elaborates on the idea by relating it to existing concepts like BECCS, blue hydrogen, and green hydrogen, and discusses its potential and challenges.
annotations.ask question: The speaker asks if others have considered this approach as an alternative source of hydrogen.

utterance: Matt Green: Yeah that's a really nice suggestion because we we've we've done we've got a project kicking off where we will capture CO2 and feed it to algae right and so ways to squeeze out a little bit more value I think are that's that's really interesting. Thanks.

annotations.Supportive response: Matt Green is expressing agreement and finding the suggestion interesting, indicating a positive evaluation of the idea.
annotations.None: No other relevant code applies to this utterance

utterance: Katherine Hornbostel: Something I've been kind of wondering about is how we're going to power all of this DAC and I know I think we already brought this up a little bit but um ARPA-E had this recent funding call that I sent a proposal for where it's like okay how can we use like a natural gas power plant you know to run DAC when it's like off peak hours. And so I've been kind of thinking along those lines and trying to brainstorm like maybe nuclear could do the same or you know maybe we need to do renewables but then those have some issues too with like land space and other issues so I don't know I'm just kind of throwing that out there as a thought. Um if anybody's kind of looked into that like you know power integration and how we're going to run all this DAC.

annotations.ask question: The speaker is requesting information on how to power DAC, asking if anybody has looked into power integration.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker highlights the need for a suitable power source for DAC, indicating a gap in current knowledge or solutions.
